articles.headline: Life and Death Decisions Weigh on Junior Officers
articles.snippet: America’s frontline troops entrust their daily lives to junior officers like Capt. Adrian Bonenberger, who must be coaches and therapists one minute, diplomats the next.
articles.abstract: America’s frontline troops entrust their daily lives to junior officers like Capt. Adrian Bonenberger, who must be coaches and therapists one minute, diplomats the next.
articles.lead_paragraph: QURGHAN TAPA, Afghanistan — The hill wasn’t much to behold, just a treeless mound of dirt barely 80 feet high. But for Taliban fighters, it was a favorite spot for launching rockets into Imam Sahib city. Ideal, American commanders figured, for the insurgents to disrupt the coming parliamentary elections.

articles.headline: Senate Support Builds for Pact on Arms Control
articles.snippet: The arms control treaty with Russia gained favor as some Republicans said they leaned toward a yes vote and a side deal took shape on missile defense.
articles.abstract: The arms control treaty with Russia gained favor as some Republicans said they leaned toward a yes vote and a side deal took shape on missile defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate moved closer on Monday to approving a new arms control treaty with Russia over the opposition of Republican leaders as lawmakers worked on a side deal to assure skeptics that the arms pact would not inhibit American plans to build missile defense systems.

articles.headline: Skype Looks for a Spot in Offices and Cellphones
articles.snippet: Skype, a financial underachiever, is trying to find new ways to make money from its 124 million users.
articles.abstract: Skype, a financial underachiever, is trying to find new ways to make money from its 124 million users.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Skype has become one of the Internet’s most popular services — so much so that it is even used as a verb to describe a phone call over the Internet, as in “Skype me.”

articles.headline: For Air Cargo, a Screening Conundrum
articles.snippet: Governments and aviation experts continue to struggle for ways to strengthen cargo security without paralyzing a business essential to global trade.
articles.abstract: Governments and aviation experts continue to struggle for ways to strengthen cargo security without paralyzing a business essential to global trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since 9/11, each new security threat to airlines has increased the rigor of passenger screening. They have to remove their shoes and carry liquids only in small containers. They have to take off their belts and take laptops out of their cases. Now, they have to submit to full-body scanning machines and intrusive pat-downs.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Seeks to Expand Raids in Pakistan
articles.snippet: Senior commanders in Afghanistan are pushing for an expanded campaign of Special Operations ground raids across the border into Pakistan, a risky strategy.
articles.abstract: Senior commanders in Afghanistan are pushing for an expanded campaign of Special Operations ground raids across the border into Pakistan, a risky strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senior American military commanders in Afghanistan are pushing for an expanded campaign of Special Operations ground raids across the border into Pakistan’s tribal areas, a risky strategy reflecting the growing frustration with Pakistan’s efforts to root out militants there.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: Antitrust Suit in Michigan Tests Health Law
articles.snippet: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan dominates the state, but a Justice Department lawsuit says the company is stifling competition.
articles.abstract: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan dominates the state, but a Justice Department lawsuit says the company is stifling competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When the Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan in October, the unusual action was widely seen as a warning shot to dominant health insurance carriers in many other states.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Is Set to Regulate Net Access
articles.snippet: The new rules would create two classes of Internet access, one for fixed-line providers and the other wireless.
articles.abstract: The new rules would create two classes of Internet access, one for fixed-line providers and the other wireless.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission appears poised to pass a controversial set of rules that broadly create two classes of Internet access, one for fixed-line providers and the other for the wireless Net.

articles.headline: E-Mail Gets an Instant Makeover
articles.snippet: Visitors to e-mail sites are in decline, and companies like Facebook now offer messaging focused on immediacy.
articles.abstract: Visitors to e-mail sites are in decline, and companies like Facebook now offer messaging focused on immediacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Signs you’re an old fogey: You still watch movies on a VCR, listen to vinyl records and shoot photos on film.
